Ask HN: What happens to BTC/ETH if secp256k1 has a backdoor
text:
I have been learning about ECDH and that the Abelian-ness (specifically the difficulty of the discrete logarithmic problem) depends on the particular curve. The NSA story around Dual_EC_DRBG did not help either.

So my question is what is the doomsday scenario? The public addresses are hashed so this should prevent anyone from having the Q of the ECDH, so in essence you won't even have the Q to be able to back into the private key P? Is this accurate?

Wikipedia: secp256k1 - " It's constants were selected in a predictable way, which significantly reduces the possibility that the curve's creator inserted any sort of backdoor into the curve."

Ask HN: Unconventional places of business to rent a desk?
text:
HN crowd, have you ever sought to rent co-working space at an unconventional place of business, like a car dealership, restaurant, or hair salon?

I am relocating to a new area soon and I prefer not to work in typical co-working hubs like WeWork due to, let's say, bad culture fit. Has anyone had success renting a desk or small office from a business that doesn't normally host programmers? Whom did you rent from, and how did you pull it off?

I'm looking for ideas.

Thanks!

Show HN: Engage followers – Reduce range dump, Increase meaningful discussions
text:
I think that most of us spend our time on Twitter usually in rage dumping because we're forced to interact with random people without common interest.

I believe if we could interact with people with common interests on Twitter then we can build meaningful relationships with them.

Fortunately we do have access to people on Twitter with common interests - Our followers; But it's currently not easy to spot what connects us with our followers as we might not follow back all our followers and even if we do there's no guarantee that we'd see all their tweets or those tweets which matter to us.

Hence I've created 'engage followers' and it works by,

1. Monitoring the tweets of our Twitter followers.

2. Classifying their tweets according to our chosen topics of interest.

3. Sending the list of tweets which matches our topics to us via an email digest and/or Auto liking them(So we can check those tweets in the likes section of Twitter).

I've seen good results over the past week since I've launched engage followers, Getting to know about some like minded followers on my personal & product accounts. I hope you'd give it a try and tell me how it can be made more useful.

Ask HN: Options for in-app advertising in a web app?
text:
I am looking to start monetizing a web-based app with ads. I would like some degree of control over where the apps are displayed and the type of ad content is allowed. Presently, the app is ONLY running as a website so the network needs to support this mode of serving ads.

What networks would be a good starting point to look at? Who are the reputable and established players in this space?

At first glance, Google AdSense does not seem to have the level of control I am looking for.

Ask HN: How can you convince companies to open up to you about pain points?
text:
As a junior, I had one job years ago where I had an opportunity to see a small business's work process. I immediately saw things that could be automated and so-called "pain points" that could be improved with software. I opened up Balsamiq, sketched up a sample of software that would solve their problems and presented it to them. They loved my ideas and paid my employer to have me make them. They were thrilled with the result and I even heard through the grapevine how much it had helped them long after I had left that company.

Years later, I'm now a senior developer. Except for that one job, my whole career has been developing a carefully refined backlog of features that are handed to me. I get to use creativity and problem-solving for technical problems, but I keep thinking wistfully back to that one junior job where I got to come up with ideas for the software and features themselves.

I don't know how to get an opportunity like that again. How would I convince a small business to let me come in and spy on their work processes so I can pitch them ideas to let me build something that would improve them? Has anyone successfully found their way in to do this?
